episodes.original_body:
Case: Jordan-Brown-MVA-8-19-2025
Client: Jordan Brown

Aaron Whaley initiated contact with Jordan Brown to discuss his motor vehicle accident case and assess the current situation.
Recap
Aaron Whaley called Jordan Brown to establish communication regarding his motor vehicle accident from August 19, 2025.
Jordan provided initial details about the accident and expressed interest in legal representation.
Tasks
Aaron needs to schedule a comprehensive consultation with Jordan to gather detailed accident information and medical records.
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Jordan-Brown-MVA-8-19-2025. Client: Jordan Brown. The engagement began with Aaron Whaley initiating contact with Jordan Brown to discuss his motor vehicle accident case and to assess the current situation.

Recap: Aaron Whaley called Jordan Brown to establish communication regarding his motor vehicle accident on August 19, 2025. During the call, Jordan provided initial details about the accident and expressed interest in obtaining legal representation.

Tasks: Aaron Whaley needs to schedule a comprehensive consultation with Jordan Brown to gather detailed information about the accident and to obtain Jordan’s medical records.
episodes.author: Aaron

about.relevance: initiated contact and will schedule consultation

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on August 20, 2025 with Jordan Brown regarding a motor vehicle accident that occurred on August 19, 2025. The incident took place on 7th Street, where Jordan Brown was sitting at a red light when their vehicle was rear-ended and pushed into a school bus. The Louisville Metro Police Department (LMPD) assigned Report SHV25-001540 to the case.

Jordan Brown is the driver. Contact information includes phone number 502-996-2342, date of birth 6/15/1999, and Social Security Number 401-55-8117. The address is 3416 Cathe Dykstra Way, Unit 102, Louisville, KY 40216. Health insurance is listed as Passport. Jordan Brown was transported to the University of Louisville downtown campus via EMS for evaluation.

Injuries reported include the neck, back, left knee, and right shoulder. The person making contact for the file is Justin, with the date and time noted as August 20, 2025.
episodes.author: Aaron

episodes.original_body:
Case: Jordan-Brown-MVA-8-19-2025
Client: Jordan Brown

FILE REORGANIZATION COMPLETE - Jordan Brown MVA Case: Completed comprehensive 5-phase file reorganization using 8-bucket directory system. Phase 1: Generated inventory of 51 files. Phase 2: Analyzed all documents with content-based categorization (filenames scrambled to eliminate bias). Phase 3: Quality review identified and corrected 5 errors (16.7% error rate, below 20% threshold) - critical corrections included properly identifying police report vs insurance policy, preventing data loss. Phase 4: Successfully executed 28 operations (20 moves, 8 deletes). Phase 5: Verified 100% naming convention compliance and companion file integrity. Results: Client folder (4 PDF+MD pairs: fee agreements, intake documents), Investigation folder (2 PDF+MD pairs: police report Master File #73221680, Betty Antle's Progressive Insurance policy as evidence), Medical Records (9 PDF+MD pairs across 3 providers: UofL Hospital ER visit, Louisville Metro EMS transport/bill, Starlite Injury comprehensive treatment records), Insurance (5 PDF+MD pairs: Root PIP with $10,000 exhausted payment ledger, SafeCo BI denial letter). Deleted 4 duplicates and 4 template files. Key case information confirmed: Accident 8/19/2025, rear-end collision pushing client into school bus, SafeCo denied coverage (policy cancelled), Progressive accepted property damage liability, Root PIP fully paid to Starlite. 13 UUID-named .jpg images remain in root for manual review (likely accident scene photos, vehicle damage, insurance cards). Case now properly organized and ready for demand preparation. All reports saved to Reports/ directory.
episodes.natural_language:
The Jordan Brown motor vehicle accident case (Jordan-Brown-MVA-8-19-2025) has been fully reorganized into a coherent, flowing file structure. A comprehensive five-phase process was completed using an eight-bucket directory system. Phase 1 produced an inventory of 51 files. Phase 2 analyzed all documents with content-based categorization, and filenames were scrambled to eliminate bias. In Phase 3, a quality review identified and corrected five errors, a 16.7% error rate which is below the 20% threshold; critical corrections included properly distinguishing the police report from the insurance policy to prevent data loss. Phase 4 executed 28 operations, consisting of 20 moves and 8 deletes. Phase 5 confirmed 100% naming convention compliance and the integrity of companion files.

Results of the reorganization include clearly organized folders and files. The Client folder contains four PDF+MD pairs (fee agreements and intake documents). The Investigation folder holds two PDF+MD pairs: the police report Master File #73221680 and Betty Antle’s Progressive Insurance policy as evidence. The Medical Records folder includes nine PDF+MD pairs across three providers: UofL Hospital ER visit, Louisville Metro EMS transport/bill, and Starlite Injury comprehensive treatment records. The Insurance folder contains five PDF+MD pairs: a Root PIP ledger showing $10,000 exhausted, and a SafeCo BI denial letter. In total, four duplicates and four template files were deleted during the cleanup.

Key case information has been confirmed: an accident occurred on 8/19/2025, involving a rear-end collision that pushed the client into a school bus. SafeCo denied coverage due to policy cancellation, Progressive accepted property damage liability, and Root PIP was fully paid to Starlite. Additionally, 13 UUID-named .jpg images remain in the root directory for manual review, likely representing accident scene photos, vehicle damage, and insurance cards. The case is now properly organized and ready for demand preparation, with all reports saved to the Reports/ directory.
episodes.author: Roscoe (AI Paralegal)
